name: Clean Energy
title: Liquified Petroleum Gas: A Bridge to a Sustainable Energy Future | RealClearEnergy
description:
When people talk about the energy transition, the conversation is often dominated by wind, solar, and hydrogen.
For billions of people and for the global energy system, the real bridge to a cleaner future is liquefied petroleum gas, or LPG.
This isn’t just a statistic; it’s a testament to the role LPG plays in accelerating the global energy transition.
LPG is often overlooked in global energy debates, but its importance cannot be overstated.
The energy transition is not a race between good and evil technologies.
text:
When people talk about the energy transition, the conversation is often dominated by wind, solar, and hydrogen. These technologies are vital for our long-term climate ambitions, but they are not the whole story. For billions of people and for the global energy system, the real bridge to a cleaner future is liquefied petroleum gas, or LPG.

BGN has built its legacy on partnership, adaptability and a commitment to sustainable progress. We hold a 10% share of the global LPG market. This isn’t just a statistic; it’s a testament to the role LPG plays in accelerating the global energy transition.

LPG is often overlooked in global energy debates, but its importance cannot be overstated. For much of the world, the choice isn’t between LPG and solar; it’s between LPG and far more harmful fuels such as coal, wood or kerosene. LPG burns cleaner than these alternatives, emitting up to 50% less carbon dioxide than coal and 20% less than heating oil. It also eliminates sulfur oxides and dramatically reduces particulate matter, improving air quality and public health.

More than two billion people still lack access to clean cooking fuels, relying on biomass and other polluting sources. These traditional fuels are linked to an estimated 3.7 million premature deaths every year, largely due to indoor air pollution. LPG offers a life-saving alternative, reducing emissions now and paving the way for future electrification. It’s not a luxury; it’s a necessity.

LPG’s versatility is another reason it’s so vital. It’s used for heating, industrial processes, agriculture, and even transportation. In regions where renewable infrastructure is limited and capital is constrained, LPG provides reliable, affordable energy that can be deployed quickly and at scale. It is a pragmatic solution for communities that cannot wait decades for solar panels or wind farms to arrive.

Critics sometimes argue that investing in LPG could delay the adoption of renewables. But this binary perspective ignores the reality on the ground. The energy transition is not a race between good and evil technologies. It is a complex, multi-stage process that must balance environmental goals with economic and social realities. LPG is not in competition with renewables; it complements them.

In fact, LPG plays a critical role in supporting renewable energy systems. It acts as a backup for intermittent power sources, enhancing energy security and grid stability. In countries with limited natural gas infrastructure, LPG generators provide reliable electricity, supporting economic development and decarbonization efforts. It is a flexible, scalable fuel that can be integrated into hybrid energy systems, making it a cornerstone of resilient energy planning.

This is where the United States comes in. As one of the world’s largest producers and exporters of LPG, the U.S. holds the key to unlocking its global potential. American infrastructure, innovation, and investment are essential to making LPG accessible and sustainable for millions of people worldwide. The U.S. has the opportunity to lead.

By expanding LPG exports, investing in cleaner production technologies, and supporting international partnerships, the U.S. can help accelerate the transition away from dirty fuels.

Moreover, the U.S. stands to benefit economically. The global demand for LPG is growing, particularly in emerging markets where energy access is still a challenge. By positioning itself as a reliable supplier of clean-burning fuels, the U.S. can strengthen its energy leadership while creating jobs and driving innovation at home.

We must also recognize the role of infrastructure. Investments in LPG terminals, storage facilities, and distribution networks are critical to ensuring that this fuel reaches those who need it most. These investments deliver real, immediate benefits: cleaner air, lower emissions, and greater energy security. They also lay the groundwork for future energy systems that are more sustainable and inclusive.

At BGN, we believe the path to sustainability requires a number of solutions. We are the largest offtaker of U.S. LPG, but are not limited to that fuel. We trade in a range of sustainability solutions, including LNG, ammonia and biofuels. We are also invested in critical minerals, which play a key role in the energy transition, and are used in wind, solar, hydrogen and nuclear energy.

The energy transition is not a straight line. It is a bridge, and LPG is one of its strongest pillars. It should get the attention it deserves.

Ruya Bayegan is CEO of BGN Group.

title: NextEra Energy partners with Google to restart Iowa nuclear plant - Yahoo Finance
description:
In this article: (Reuters) -U.S. utility NextEra Energy (NEE) and Alphabet's Google (GOOG) have singed a power supply deal, which would help restart the Duane Arnold nuclear plant in Iowa.
Shares of NextEra Energy rose over 1% to $87.24 after the bell.
86.03 +1.62 +(1.92%) At close: 4:00:02 PM EDT The over 600-megawatt Duane Arnold Energy Center was shut in 2020 after operating for 45 years.
Duane Arnold Energy Center, located in Palo, Iowa, is the only nuclear power plant in the state and is expected to reopen by first quarter of 2029, NextEra said.
One of the plant's minority owners, Central Iowa Power Cooperative (CIPCO), will purchase the remaining portion of the plant's output on the same terms as Google, NextEra said.
text:
In this article:

(Reuters) -U.S. utility NextEra Energy (NEE) and Alphabet's Google (GOOG) have singed a power supply deal, which would help restart the Duane Arnold nuclear plant in Iowa.

After years of stagnation, the nuclear industry is witnessing a renaissance, driven by a huge surge in power demand as Big Tech looks for clean energy sources to power their data centers.

Shares of NextEra Energy rose over 1% to $87.24 after the bell.

86.03

+1.62

+(1.92%)

At close: 4:00:02 PM EDT

The over 600-megawatt Duane Arnold Energy Center was shut in 2020 after operating for 45 years. No fully shut U.S. nuclear reactor has been brought back to life, but Duane Arnold would be among three plants in the country in the process of attempted restarts.

Duane Arnold Energy Center, located in Palo, Iowa, is the only nuclear power plant in the state and is expected to reopen by first quarter of 2029, NextEra said.

Under the 25-year agreement, the tech giant will purchase power from the 615-MW plant for its growing cloud and AI infrastructure in the state, while also driving significant economic investment to the Midwest region.

One of the plant's minority owners, Central Iowa Power Cooperative (CIPCO), will purchase the remaining portion of the plant's output on the same terms as Google, NextEra said.

The utility added that it had also signed agreements to acquire CIPCO and Corn Belt Power Cooperative's combined 30% interest in the Duane Arnold plant, bringing NextEra's ownership to 100%.

(Reporting by Vallari Srivastava in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

name: EPA
title: EPA Prioritizes TSCA Review of New Chemicals Used in Data Centers | JD Supra
description:
Efforts are underway to support data center development with respect to new chemicals that may be used in such projects.
EPA has provided instructions on what to include in a cover letter to receive priority review of new chemicals to be used in data centers or corresponding infrastructure and components.
“A submission will be accepted for prioritized review if there are concrete steps taken toward planning the project and there is a tangible relationship between the submitter and an entity involved in the project planning.” Following a roundtable with AI and data center leaders at the White House on Monday, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lee Zeldin announced that it will be prioritizing the review of new chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) that are intended for use in data center projects or for the manufacturing of covered components, as defined by Executive Order 14318, “Accelerating Federal Permitting of Data Center Infrastructure.” This prioritization of reviews will start with submissions received on or after September 29, 2025. www.epa.gov/...
text:
Efforts are underway to support data center development with respect to new chemicals that may be used in such projects. EPA has provided instructions on what to include in a cover letter to receive priority review of new chemicals to be used in data centers or corresponding infrastructure and components. “A submission will be accepted for prioritized review if there are concrete steps taken toward planning the project and there is a tangible relationship between the submitter and an entity involved in the project planning.”

Following a roundtable with AI and data center leaders at the White House on Monday, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lee Zeldin announced that it will be prioritizing the review of new chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) that are intended for use in data center projects or for the manufacturing of covered components, as defined by Executive Order 14318, “Accelerating Federal Permitting of Data Center Infrastructure.” This prioritization of reviews will start with submissions received on or after September 29, 2025.

www.epa.gov/...
